review_preview: Having read a lot of reviews of places in Spain (in English) there are often misconceptions and false expectations from tourists who don’t necessarily know how things work in Spain. I had the same experience in Italy, it took a few times to get a...
review_full: Having read a lot of reviews of places in Spain (in English) there are often misconceptions and false expectations from tourists who don’t necessarily know how things work in Spain. I had the same experience in Italy, it took a few times to get a feel of how the locals operate and are expected to behave in a bar environment like these. First up, with Casa Alberto, being a genuine old bar, the best place is actually at the bar, standing. The staff are not rude but just efficient. Order a drink such as the popular vermouth (vermut) or a caña of beer, you will be given tapas of different kinds. The food is classic Madrid and their oxtail stew (rabo), snails (caracoles) and Madrid style offal which is tripe, pig snout, ears, blood sausage (callos) were outstanding and have not had anywhere that topped it in my travels. The atmosphere is always lively, especially during the Spanish meal times.

title_review: Atmosphere great, quality not so much
review_preview: Alberto’s is long on atmosphere, but the quality of the food isn’t very good.  The dining room is really for tourists—it’s clearly a very old, traditional restaurant with a great deal of charm, and if that’s what you’re looking for you’ll be satisfied.  But my...
review_full: Alberto’s is long on atmosphere, but the quality of the food isn’t very good. The dining room is really for tourists—it’s clearly a very old, traditional restaurant with a great deal of charm, and if that’s what you’re looking for you’ll be satisfied. But my wife’s hake was old, and the sauce on it tasted like it came out of a can. My squid was just OK. The tapas plates we saw in the front room didn’t look all that appetizing. The waiters were rather brusque, as other reviewers have noted, but that’s just a certain style in traditional Madrid restaurants with all-male wait-staffs, so it didn’t bother us. It’s the quality of the food—you can do much better than this in Madrid.

review_preview: Great food, friendly service, huge portions. Almost passed this restaurant up because we prefer to eat outdoors weather permitting. We are so glad we braved the noise and crowds to eat here. My husband, daughter and I each ordered a Sangria which arrived in large...
review_full: Great food, friendly service, huge portions. Almost passed this restaurant up because we prefer to eat outdoors weather permitting. We are so glad we braved the noise and crowds to eat here. My husband, daughter and I each ordered a Sangria which arrived in large glasses and with a free tapa of chorizo mini sausages in a tasty sauce with little strips of toast. We ordered three tapas to share; huevos y jamon over piping hot, crispy French fries, gambas(grilled whole shrimp) and paella marisco (seafood). I couldn't believe how large the plates of food were and didn't think we could eat all of it, but somehow we managed. A complimentary basket of bread accompanied our meal. We couldn't eat any of the bread because we were just too full. The gambas were delicious, not to be missed. Our waiter was super attentive even though he was really busy. Our entire bill came to €30. After 17 days in Spain, this meal was one of the best we had.

title_review: Our favorite place for tapas in Madrid.
review_preview: We have been to Madrid three times and always go to the Mercado de San Miguel! There is a wonderful wine bar where you can get a glass of wine or a bottle with glasses and then move on to your favorite food spot. For...
review_full: We have been to Madrid three times and always go to the Mercado de San Miguel! There is a wonderful wine bar where you can get a glass of wine or a bottle with glasses and then move on to your favorite food spot. For us that spot is the food bar at the end of the Mercado closest to the Plaza Mayor. They have the best huevos rotos con jamon and pimientos de padron that we have had anywhere in Spain! In addition, they have all kinds of fresh traditionally prepared seafood (the grilled sepia is my favorite). It is a very friendly place where it is impossible to not have conversation with fellow patrons from all over the world!

review_preview: I think we can all agree that if your reading my review, its because you like indian food right? Well, so do I, and a LOT. Like always, every city I go I look for an Indian restaraunt, and I found this one on tripadvisor....
review_full: I think we can all agree that if your reading my review, its because you like indian food right? Well, so do I, and a LOT. Like always, every city I go I look for an Indian restaraunt, and I found this one on tripadvisor.  When i went there I found the place a little cheap, i had my doubts. We got served right away with a very friendly waiter. He reccommend us some plates when we asked for spice.  Right away we received a yummy kind of crunchy thin bread and some sauces, really good. Then we ordered 5 plates( tandoorri, shrimp curry, massala, chutney mango and another one i forgot), 2 side rices and 3 breads(paratah, garlic naan and naan). The food was a little slow tbh. But it didnt matter, as soon as i tasted the massala, i got swept away. It was delicious, just like the other plates. The naans were on point, but like Mei Mei C wrote the paratah want that great honestly. But still, delicious. Now, the food is cheap but it tastes expensive and theres a lot of food, we even left some( and there were 5 hungry, indian cusine lovers). And the water was the bomb too.  Recomendations: •chicken massala •tandoori •order 1 rice for at least 4-5 people •garlic and normal naan •water

review_preview: Having recently been to Benares, it was good to go back to Lavapies for some authentic Indian food, and we paid the same for a family of 5 that we paid per person at Benares...22 of us sat outside and the service was very...
review_full: Having recently been to Benares, it was good to go back to Lavapies for some authentic Indian food, and we paid the same for a family of 5 that we paid per person at Benares... 22 of us sat outside and the service was very good considering how many we were. Excellent onion bhajis and some well spiced samosas to start. Chicken tikka masala, decently spicy prawn jalfrezi, bhindi bhaji, baigan bhaji, tarka dall and a great lamb methi, which wasn't on the menu but we asked for anyway. All very good and seriously impressed our Spanish friends. We'll be back soon.

title_review: Delicious South Asian food and great service
review_preview: Great place! The sauces with the papadums (raita, mango chutney, spicy sauce) were homemade and very delicious. Then I had the meat samosa, and butter chicken with white rice. I asked for the butter chicken to be spiced up a bit extra, and they were...
review_full: Great place! The sauces with the papadums (raita, mango chutney, spicy sauce) were homemade and very delicious. Then I had the meat samosa, and butter chicken with white rice. I asked for the butter chicken to be spiced up a bit extra, and they were happy to oblige. Feroz as well as the rest of the staff provided excellent service, and I even got a super yummy mango lassi on the house. A point of improvement might be the interior; the red gingham tablecloths along with the green chair covers don't really match. The pictures on the walls are beautiful, but the interior maybe needs to be rearranged in order to be consistent with the traditional image of the restaurant. I had a great experience having traditional South Asian food at Moharaj, and I will definitely go back when I'm in Madrid.

review_full: I tried a number of the curry houses in Lavapiés while living in Madrid, but stopped as soon as I found Moharaj 18 - I knew instantly that nothing would beat this one! On future visits to Madrid, even though I'll probably feel a bit guilty going for a curry and not something 'more local', I'll no doubt be returning!

review_preview: I will keep this short - lovely busy atmosphere and plenty to look at, but the food we tried was mostly terrible, overpriced, cold and bland. There was a lot of fish on offer, which we didnt try alot of. However I tried 5 selections...
review_full: I will keep this short - lovely busy atmosphere and plenty to look at, but the food we tried was mostly terrible, overpriced, cold and bland. There was a lot of fish on offer, which we didnt try alot of. However I tried 5 selections from one vender which were all stone cold, and tasted like cheap supermarket party nibbles (Iceland in the UK came to mind as being superior). However there is a lady selling Italian food, We got a slice of Lasagna to reheat for our sleeping toddler later - it was very good for 2 euros. The central bar selling lots of food also had decent batatas bravas. The wine is nice from the stall in the middle of the cheese and meat counters (5.50 for two small chunks of warm cheese, hard bread and small glass of wine). The lady selling a wide array of desserts/patisserie at one end could not have been ruder to my wife who was spending 15 euros on some treats - terrible service. This is clearly just a tourist trap that will quickly draw money from your wallet for very average food. Worth a quick look, but remember 'not all that glistens is gold'!  2.5/5 stars would be more apt.

Enjoyed a few versions of salmon, 1 euro each. Tried some excellent baklava. A fun, energetic place to go and a good place to meet tourists from all parts of the globe. A few locals who seemed to know the best deals could also be found.

title_review: Watered down beer. Disappointing service, OK food
review_preview: It was busy on a weekday night - a good sign. A bad start with the beer: ordered a draught Mahou which arrived cloudy and with a very slight cleaning fluidy taste. I also had the impression from the thinness that it was watered down,...
review_full: It was busy on a weekday night - a good sign. A bad start with the beer: ordered a draught Mahou which arrived cloudy and with a very slight cleaning fluidy taste. I also had the impression from the thinness that it was watered down, which happens quite a bit in cheap restaurants. Twenty years of drinking beer (almost as much of a fan as Judge Kavanaugh is) and you get to know what’s been messed with. So I pointed this out and was going to ask for a bottled beer instead, but the waiter looked annoyed, argued that there was nothing wrong, but immediately replaced it with another, equally cloudy and watery one. Maybe not the first complaint. So after sending that back I ordered a bottle of Mahou - same stuff - which when poured was crisp clear and just right. The attitude of the waiter was hostile at this point so I thought about walking out, just paying for the beer, but I had ordered the two courses at the start, and it was raining, so hey ho.  Dhal soup was good: quite garlicky, hot and tasty. Vindaloo also was fine, boneless chicken and a medium dry sauce, about the spiciness I was expecting. Rice was also perfectly fine. No complaints about the food. This is a cheap-looking place, one of about ten in the neighbourhood, and one of the most successful, it looks like, but they must sort out their draught beer, and not cheat the customers. A trading standards officer would be all over them in the U.K. - if there’s a Spanish one around, please go test the beer purity! At least they did not even try to charge for the two draught beers. If you go here, stick to the bottled beer, but I would try another curry place if I were you given the unfriendliness of the staff. The curry tasted good but the attitude (and the adulterated draught Mahou) left a bad taste in the mouth.

The restaurant has a Jazz theme design with albums and posters of various artists.

Began with a wonderfully fresh salad, then enjoyed the chipirones which were also among the best I've had in Spain. The presa ibérica was also fantastic with a flavourful sauce that really took it to the next level. Delicious desserts ended the meal. The wine list here is long enough to have something for everyone, all good quality. Waiters are professional, helpful, and truly know the menu. The prices are very fair. During my next visit to Madrid, I will stop in here to enjoy the other menu items.

Very much reminiscent of old New Orleans restaurants. At first our server was rather brusque, but as the meal went on and we chatted with him he warmed up considerably and provided excellent service. Carrillada de Ternera (veal cheeks) were quite good. Albóndigas de Ternera (meatballs) were good, although a little on the blander side. Tomato and tuna salad tasty. Good wine list. A very leisurely-paced and enjoyable lunch.

But the food is delish so I had to.  As soon as you sit down, they bring you free tapas! It varies from your waiter. We had meat and cheeses. Table next to us got baked items. Sangria was only a few euros! And delish! I came in just for drinks but after looking at the menu, I had to have the food. And I'm glad I did. We opted for their house paella since it was a Sunday and apparently, they make a special version. It has crab, shellfish and all things fun. I liked it. But the plate that steal the show was the plancha! Aka the girlled item aka with massive prawns. Oh so tastyyyyyyy. Smoky, sweet, succulent langostinos/ prawns! It was beautiful! Worth getting your hands dirty! It's just delish! I also wanted to try a few other items but they weren't ready or sold out. But if you make it here, try the drinks! Try the seafood! its pretty darn good.

Rare in Spain is a lot more rare that in the UK so I changed how I'd like it cooked accordingly. It was perfect! The octopus starter...delicious! But you have to be brave, it very much looks like an octopus- not cut up or battered etc!

review_preview: We first visited here in 2001, and we have returned on each succeeding trip (5 in all).  It is a pleasure to find that someplace this unique has not changed (so many places have) except for maybe the clientelle, which seems now to be largely...
review_full: We first visited here in 2001, and we have returned on each succeeding trip (5 in all). It is a pleasure to find that someplace this unique has not changed (so many places have) except for maybe the clientelle, which seems now to be largely made up of fussy tourists.  On this most recent trip we finally had formal dining in the back room, having previously just gone tapas-crazy in the front area. It was a truly fine dining experience: sweetbreads for me and merluza for my wife, served with care and pride--we are still talking about it. If you just need some wine and tapas, order the albondegas (spicey meatballs in a rich sauce) and the house red wine. If you feel underserved, ripped-off or in any other way dissatisfied (as some previous posters seem to be complaining of) just give up on experiencing the real Madrid. From the look of things, it doesn't seem that this place is in jeapordy of closing. If it ever does, we will weep.

title_review: Very tasty food in a nice place. We suggest it.
review_preview: During a holiday week-end in Madrid, we've been here for some tapas, suggested by a guide.The place is very ancient and typical, and crowdy also. We had a fried cod, very good, a brownie of "morcilla" ( a sort of sausage made of blood),...
review_full: During a holiday week-end in Madrid, we've been here for some tapas, suggested by a guide. The place is very ancient and typical, and crowdy also.  We had a fried cod, very good, a brownie of "morcilla" ( a sort of sausage made of blood), delicious, and manitas de cordero ( lamb's hands) that is absolutely fantastic. Finally dessert: fruit gazpacho, fresh and good, and a chocolate little cake, a little to dry. To drink: "Tinto de verano", a little to light, we've drunk better ones in Madrid. Service at the desk was so and so, but when we found two seats the tables waiter was perfect and very friendly. Bill as other ancient tapas bar in Madrid. We Strongly suggest it.

Don't bother going into the restaurant just stand/sit in the bar at the front and order lots of tapas plates with red wine. The staff are lovely and will help you if you're unsure (they didn't want to bring me sweetbreads until I reassured them I knew what they were)  This is my happy place and one day I'll go there after having watched Wolves win the Champions League in the Bernabeu and be the happiest person in the whole world

review_preview: This is a review about the restaurant bit. We were recommended this restaurant as its very old and was meant to be a nice restaurant to visit. We got in and there was a wait which was fine. It is a very small place so...
review_full: This is a review about the restaurant bit. We were recommended this restaurant as its very old and was meant to be a nice restaurant to visit. We got in and there was a wait which was fine. It is a very small place so we had to wait in the tapas bit of the restaurant. As we were waiting, one of the waiters in the tapas section was so rude - my mother was slightly in his way but we didn't realise. He could have said excuse me - but instead he just pushed her away and made what sounded like a very abrupt comment as he did this. No apology or acknowledgement of this. We were so hungry and the waiter who had asked us to wait had been nice so we decided to still wait. When we did eventually get seated the food I found was quite expensive for what it was and lacked real flavor - it was all very bland and disappointing. If you do go there do not order the soup! It had soggy bread and egg in it...yuck! Though the waiters who all spoke English were friendly. They were not very attentive. They took a while to get things for us that we asked for. The only positive was the setting - we were seated at the back with lots of pictures and signed photographs of bull fighters so it had a nice feel to it and that for me was the only redeeming part of my experience. I would however not recommend as its overpriced and the food and customer service leaves a lot to be desired.

Again in the central area of Madrid (a couple of blocks from the Sol metro).

title_review: Great for a visit but expensive and a tourist trap
review_preview: If you don’t mind paying 4.50 euros for 4 prawns that were probably cooked 6 hours ago and been sitting under a heat lamp all day or 3.50 for a tiny quiche, Also get crushed all the way round with nowhere to sit or even...
review_full: If you don’t mind paying 4.50 euros for 4 prawns that were probably cooked 6 hours ago and been sitting under a heat lamp all day or 3.50 for a tiny quiche, Also get crushed all the way round with nowhere to sit or even stand and eat, then this is the place for you. We stopped at a shop called shandy I think, asked for a chicken pasty and a small quiche (6 euros for the 2) , the lady tried to keep selling us other stuff that she had loads of and said do you want this cheese croquette at 2.50, I said no thanks and she said so you don’t like cheese then and gave me a funny look, I said no just the things we’ve ordered, I was almost ready to walk away at this point but gave her a 20 note and she gave me change of a 10 mostly in coppers, I told her it was wrong and she reluctantly gave me a 10 note. Maybe it was just this one stall but it really put us off. The market has a wonderful array of foods and drinks but be prepared to spend a fortune if your hungry or thirsty.  My tip is to go in, walk round everything, take pictures then go outside and find another place to eat/drink.  Instead go to Atocha station and get the train to Malaga , the market there is way better and not a tourist rip off place like this! In fact Malaga is a better city overall in my opinion, and Seville and Toledo and Córdoba!

review_preview: Chef Mario Payan exudes confidence in his work, and masters perfectly the art which is Japanese cuisine. Since my lunch at Jiro in Ginza last year, I have not found such a pure Japanese restaurant in the world (apart Nakazawa, NYC). Kappo has the advantage...
review_full: Chef Mario Payan exudes confidence in his work, and masters perfectly the art which is Japanese cuisine.  Since my lunch at Jiro in Ginza last year, I have not found such a pure Japanese restaurant in the world (apart Nakazawa, NYC). Kappo has the advantage of having access to a large variety of fresh fish from the Atlantic and Mediterranean sea. This is what I look for in a Japanese restaurant: 1) Dedication and 2) Fresh produce.  The nigiri is served like in Japan, one by one in a relatively quick cadence allowing you to taste 16-18 delicious nigiris. I don't look for Nobu or Zuma style Japanese with inventive appetizers and tiraditos etc. What I look is for the lukewarm rice with the best fish on top. Full stop. It is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the world. I would rank it 3rd in the world behind Jiro (Tokyo) and Nakazawa (NYC). It is the best in Europe.

We found so many stalls with mouthwatering dishes from a variety of empanadas to interesting pintxos to Iberian ham to fresh seafood to sweets - you will find pretty much anything here! Including sangrias, wine, and beer! It is a place bustling with what seemed to be mostly tourists and so the prices here are a little bit higher than you will find elsewhere in Madrid. Still- it's fun to see and I would go here again.

title_review: One of the best, if not the best Japanese restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: I have visited a few of them, and Kappo has impressed me.Maro Payan elaborates a fine, flavoured and exquisite set menu (I don't know if they offer a la carte).Yo just need to sit down and expect to be surprised. For sure, you...
review_full: I have visited a few of them, and Kappo has impressed me. Maro Payan elaborates a fine, flavoured and exquisite set menu (I don't know if they offer a la carte). Yo just need to sit down and expect to be surprised. For sure, you will be surprised. The quality of fish, freshness and the clean and accurate cuts is amazing. The mix of flavors and the basic, yet excellent presentation of each bite makes Kappo, at least, for me, one of the best if not the best Japanese restaurants in Madrid. Mario uses a blend of two different vinegars to mix the rice so that rice has a pinkish colour differebt to all I have seen. This "secret" dates from some 120 years ago. I visited the place with my son. Totalling 130€ including a couple of wines each.

title_review: Madrid institution not to be missed
review_preview: This restaurant was recommended to us by a friend so we booked a table (pays to book as it is small and usually fills up) during our recent visit to Madrid.  We were tucked in a table in a corner surrounded by years of memorabilia...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended to us by a friend so we booked a table (pays to book as it is small and usually fills up) during our recent visit to Madrid. We were tucked in a table in a corner surrounded by years of memorabilia on the walls. To start were were given a complementary appetizer of deep fried huge green olives which were amazing. Then I had the beef checks and my partner had the oxtail, both absolutely delicious washed down with plenty of Spanish red wine as recommended by our waiter. We were very relaxed and loving the atmosphere so we stayed for dessert which was also yummy. Fantastic food, friendly service, loads of history and atmosphere. The best place we ate in Madrid by far.

review_full: We stumbled on La Antonita on our first night in Madrid, and I'm really glad we did. The wine was lovely, and really reasonably priced and the service was good. The highlight for us was definitely the squid, possibly the best squid we'd ever had! For dessert order green tea chocolates or red bean cakes. Delicious!

title_review: Great brewery tucked away off of Gran Via

review_full: FM is a great brewery to stop in any time they are open. The staff are very friendly. You will find locals and tourists alike. They offer olives or peanuts for a tapas to go along with your beer and usually ask which you prefer. There is also a small menu of assorted meats and cheeses. There is not always seating available, but that's because they are a small establishment at this point and very popular. Squeeze your way to the bar and order a drink! A seat or two will eventually open up or just enjoy standing with your delicious craft beer. Enjoy! You're in Spain!

review_full: There are quite a number of Japanese restaurants in Madrid, but none as authentic as Musashi. The food is similar to what you can find in a good Japanese restaurant in Asia, and quality is of certain standard. The sushi is fresh, and various rice bowls (Don) for both the cooked food (teriyaki chicken or beef or Unagi) and raw fishes (Chirashi don) are of reasonable standard. The Gyoza is worth trying as it is really good!! Overall a good dining experience. The price is slightly on the high side, but I guess with most good Japanese restaurants this is to be expected.

review_preview: La Antonita is a tapas restaurant and part of the Posada del Dragon. Is divided in 2 rooms; a semi-open court (smoking area) which is basically the court area of the hotel and an inside one with walls and floor of warm wood. In this...
review_full: La Antonita is a tapas restaurant and part of the Posada del Dragon. Is divided in 2 rooms; a semi-open court (smoking area) which is basically the court area of the hotel and an inside one with walls and floor of warm wood. In this room there are few tables than the other room with a food preparation station on one side. Menu fairly small, which in general I like particularly for small restaurants, but being a tapas restaurant we found the choices a little too limited. Started with two types of croquettes (OK but not glorious, continued with a tomato salad (different variety of tomatoes with a touch of sweet marmalade, way too big) then grilled squids and cazuela de mariscos (All a little predictable and lame). Overall it was ok but nothing really new or particularly original. Bread was hard and cold. The wine (Rueda) was very good. Staff was smiley and courteous. Price around 80 Euros. I would put few more tapas items in the menus and push a little more the creativity in the kitchen blending traditional with new element of the Spanish and International cuisine.

title_review: Fantastic micro brewery!! Worth a visit!
review_preview: Our friend found a review of this pub in a Guardian article on Masrid. It is located in a street off Gran Via. The pub is modern, with the brewing equipment on view. The young lady serving was very helpful with beer choices and serving...
review_full: Our friend found a review of this pub in a Guardian article on Masrid. It is located in a street off Gran Via. The pub is modern, with the brewing equipment on view. The young lady serving was very helpful with beer choices and serving to our table. We ordered sausage and cheese tapas with wonderful dark crusty beer bread. The cheese was served in oil and was very mature, ideal with beer. The craft beer was excellent. There were 3 choices of sizes along with 7 choices of beer, stout, red ale, wheat beer, Malasana, Valverde and Flipa. The men preferred the Malasana and would have stayed all night if we had let them. The bill with 13 servings of beer, two plates of sausage and one of cheese came to €48.40, see photo of bill for details.

That alone would be good enough but their other beers are great, they're generous with the tapas, the food is well in line with the rest of Madrid's bars and the owners are lovely people. I rarely enjoy small bars but this one just seems very friendly and relaxed even when very full. I can't praise it highly enough.

But the Mercado de San Miguel is by far the best thing the Madrid tourist area has to offer.  Wine, sangria (homemade at pretty much every place), everything you could ever think of (purses, wallets, etc.) made from cork, tapas, seafood, paella, cheese, cured meats (in Spain, I advise living on jamon iberico which most Americans know as the Italian 'prosciutto').  An excellent venue where you can peruse at your leisure, purchase a la carte whatever suits your fancy and surely accommodate everyone in your party.

title_review: Better than eating in a restaurant
review_preview: We stumbled across The Mercado de San Miguel this afternoon and had one of the best experiences of our trip yet. The gourmet market offers you the chance to try beautiful Spanish cuisine in a tapas style. The various different counters host a range of...
review_full: We stumbled across The Mercado de San Miguel this afternoon and had one of the best experiences of our trip yet. The gourmet market offers you the chance to try beautiful Spanish cuisine in a tapas style. The various different counters host a range of foods from desserts and pastries, to fresh shellfish and meats and cheeses. There are also various counters to buy wine, beer or sangria. It's a great change from a restaurant for people who are interested in food and many of the tapas are relatively inexpensive. The only problem you might have is trying to decide what to try!

review_preview: I absolutely loved Madrid and places like this are one of the reasons why. This bar was a real highlight of our trip to Madrid.Fabrica Maravillas serve beers that they brew right there on site. As a huge fan of 'craft' beer, and as...
review_full: I absolutely loved Madrid and places like this are one of the reasons why. This bar was a real highlight of our trip to Madrid. Fabrica Maravillas serve beers that they brew right there on site. As a huge fan of 'craft' beer, and as a novice homebrewer myself, this place really appealed to me. You can see the fermenters behind the bar. Brilliant stuff. The beers were absolutely fantastic and I didn't have a bad one and we were there all night. You could have smaller 'third' size glasses which mean that you could try a few. The bar lady (sorry I didn't get your name) was friendly, very knowledgeable and passionate about the beers and she was a credit to the bar.  I guess some people would say it's slightly expensive but I don't think it is when you consider what you are getting. If you want drink your weight in pretty average, mass produced beers then there are tonnes of good bars around Madrid where you can do so. If you want something different, with character and made with passion then pay a few cents more and drink here - your taste buds will thank you for it.

title_review: one of the best food markets, though very turisty
review_preview: We love food markets. on our travels we love visiting local food markets and get a feeling of the local cuisine and atmosphere. We visited Chelsea Market in NY, Sarona market in TLV and many others.San Miguel is truly one of the best with...
review_full: We love food markets. on our travels we love visiting local food markets and get a feeling of the local cuisine and atmosphere. We visited Chelsea Market in NY, Sarona market in TLV and many others. San Miguel is truly one of the best with a wide verity of local dishes, Tapas and Pinchos at the right size (small) to try few, and even greater verity of drinks, local wines, specialty Sangria (we had the strawberry pineapple - YUMMMM). It was very crowded, packed with tourists, not many locals (even though we were there for lunch time) and an occasional hit in the head from careless selfy stick was annoying but acceptable. Try to visit before or after crazy meal times and the experience might be even better.

title_review: Not as good as I'd hoped
review_preview: I normally make a beeline for the local market when on hols, food is great value, good quality and it's always full of locals. This felt like something set up for tourists. generally I found the food to be overpriced (8 euros for a plate...
review_full: I normally make a beeline for the local market when on hols, food is great value, good quality and it's always full of locals. This felt like something set up for tourists. generally I found the food to be overpriced (8 euros for a plate of padron peppers?) Although most of it was tasty. The exception was L'hardy which I was hoping would be good given the positive reviews of the restaurant. Alas no - the server foisted food on us that we didn't really want (and charged for it) and the one dish I had asked for - scallops - was cold and unpleasant, I didn't bother eating it. There's a nice buzz in the market and lots of pretty stalls/bars so do go for a drink - but I wouldn't recommend as a destination for food when the city is brimful of better and cheaper tapas bars.

title_review: Great looking food but pricey for what you get
review_preview: Great looking market with great looking food.  You can get a taste of all things spanish - empanadas from Galicia, gazpacho from Andalucia,  chorizo, ham, tinto de verano, vermouth, desserts... But for the price, you don't get a lot. €1 gets you barely a mouthful...

You can get a taste of all things spanish - empanadas from Galicia, gazpacho from Andalucia, chorizo, ham, tinto de verano, vermouth, desserts... review_preview: This little market was amazing. Its been completely redone in the past 10 years, the iron and glass mercado that had fallen into disrepair but it has been beautifully redone (and is now a certified “green” building). Its home to about thirty vendors selling everything...
review_full: This little market was amazing. Its been completely redone in the past 10 years, the iron and glass mercado that had fallen into disrepair but it has been beautifully redone (and is now a certified “green” building). Its home to about thirty vendors selling everything from coffee and pastries to ham and wine. There wasn’t a single thing in this market that wasn’t delicious. We made it here everyday (one day even twice) to grab a meal. Its an excellent mix of local people and tourists. Its interesting to watch the change in the crowd through out the day, the morning is filled with many families and tourists looking for a meal but at night (its open late, because its Spain) it turns into an awesome place to have a glass of Sangria or wine while eating some delicious thing you just bought off one of the stands. Be warned though, at times this market is packed (so packed I can’t walk anywhere without spilling my wine, and not from having too much). This is why night time is the best time to go, or just don’t go on a weekend. We went Monday before we caught the metro to the airport and we basically had the place to ourselves. Bonus: its right off the Plaza Mayor, so basically you don’t have an excuse not to go.

review_preview: We refer to this as "the fancy market" because it is more upscale compared to the other market nearby (San Anton?). Probably not for everyone because you do pay more for the presentation but to us it was worth every penny. It can be tough...
review_full: We refer to this as "the fancy market" because it is more upscale compared to the other market nearby (San Anton?). Probably not for everyone because you do pay more for the presentation but to us it was worth every penny. It can be tough to find a seat but if you're not in a rush you will eventually get one. I suggest going on an empty stomach and when you have lots of free time.  As for the food, here are a few of our faves: 1. The mozzarella bar located in one of the back corner - here you can get whipped mozzarella with various toppings. It is like nothing I've ever tasted before - so yummy! 2. Meat cones from the meat vendors - different types available and all delicious! 3. The sweets vendor - here we got churros con chocolate, macarons and a slice of meringue cake - all were fab! We don't recommend the paella here - it was basically a bowl of salty rice and we have had much better at different restaurants. Enjoy!

title_review: How To Do Vermouth in Madrid
review_preview: If you are visiting Madrid and want to experience Vermouth culture begin at Casa Alberto.  There are old school manners, an endless stream of vermouth and canas being poured, and a delightful variety of tapas available. Order from the chalkboard over the bar and not...
review_full: If you are visiting Madrid and want to experience Vermouth culture begin at Casa Alberto. There are old school manners, an endless stream of vermouth and canas being poured, and a delightful variety of tapas available. Order from the chalkboard over the bar and not from the menu, and sit at one of the rustic tables if you are lucky enough to get there early. If not, then elbow in at the bar and make yourself known to the friendly bartenders who will be glad to twist an orange or an olive into your glass. Sweet red is what the locals like, and you must try some.

review_preview: We were welcomed to this restaurant by a very friendly waiter who spoke perfect English and took great trouble to ensure we enjoyed our evening.Our visit was relatively early in the evening by Madrid standards so the restaurant started fairly quiet, although by 8.30...
review_full: We were welcomed to this restaurant by a very friendly waiter who spoke perfect English and took great trouble to ensure we enjoyed our evening. Our visit was relatively early in the evening by Madrid standards so the restaurant started fairly quiet, although by 8.30 it was starting to get quite busy. Even so, the same high standard of service continued. We had been a bit disappointed with the food in Madrid but this was the best meal of our stay. Prices are reasonable, internal decor is pleasant and the seating is comfortable. We ordered a very large plate of meat which the waiter was convinced we wouldn't finish (he underestimated us) but kept coming back to ensure it was cooked to our liking. I recommend this restaurant and it will be the first one we visit next time we are in Madrid. It is located a very short walk south of Puerta del Sol.

review_preview: My wife and I dined at Casa Alberto last Wednesday. We shared a pickled chicken salad starter followed by hake for my wife and steak for myself. My wife chose the crepe dish for dessert. All courses were full of flavour, cooked well and presented...
review_full: My wife and I dined at Casa Alberto last Wednesday. We shared a pickled chicken salad starter followed by hake for my wife and steak for myself. My wife chose the crepe dish for dessert. All courses were full of flavour, cooked well and presented superbly. To be safe I asked for my steak to be cooked medium and, fortunately, it came back as medium rare which I preferred but was too scared to ask for. Casa Alberto has a lovely atmosphere whether you choose to eat at the tables in the bar area or in the restaurant. There's so much to grab your attention in both the bar and in the restaurant. The waiter was very attentive and there was just the right length of time between courses. If you are looking for a special meal then I would thoroughly recommend Casa Alberto. Reservations in the restaurant appeared to begin at 8.00 pm.

review_preview: My husband and I spent 6 nights in Madrid in September, 2013.  Our B&B (the wonderful Artistic B&B) was close to Casa Alberto. We went there 4 times. That is because the food is second to none. MInd you, this place is busy but well...
review_full: My husband and I spent 6 nights in Madrid in September, 2013. Our B&B (the wonderful Artistic B&B) was close to Casa Alberto. We went there 4 times. That is because the food is second to none. MInd you, this place is busy but well worth a short wait for a table (unless you want to stand). The tapas bar is in the front and there is a restaurant in the back for a dinner menu, which we did not try. Next time. Every dish we had up front was most delicious and presented like a four star restaurant. But the best thing about Casa Alberto is Herman, our waiter. He was very entertaining and patient with us being we speak no Spanish. He often brought some free samples and treated us like friends. We miss Casa Alberto and hope to go back to Madrid some day.

title_review: Good dinner in Madrid city centre!

review_full: While going around for the city without deciding where to have our dinner, we saw this restaurant and, among all others, we decided to stop here. Well, it was actually a good decision! There are not so many tables, and the atmosphere is really nice with all waiters running around taking orders and bringing food and drinks.  At the entrance there is a bar where you can eat tapas standing there. If you prefer, you can wait (as we did) for a free table. There is a dedicated menu for who is sitting, but - maybe because it was already late - they allowed us to choose also among the tapas bar menu. Really kinf of them. So we took an house speciality (meat ball with a sauce) and bacalao croquette. Also the dessert (a cake) was good. Suggested!

review_preview: We received this restaurant as a recommendation from our hotel. I’m usually skeptical of these recommendations, but this one turned out to be lovely. The food was outstanding. We were the only tourists in the restaurant. Our waiter did not speak English. For us that...
review_full: We received this restaurant as a recommendation from our hotel. I’m usually skeptical of these recommendations, but this one turned out to be lovely. The food was outstanding. We were the only tourists in the restaurant. Our waiter did not speak English. For us that was a positive in looking for a local restaurant. We sat at a table next to some locals and they were quite friendly. When we didn’t order wine, they offered us some of theirs. We ordered the Cod fish dish and the bean and ox tail and baby lamb chops. All of the dishes were delicious. (When eating the baby lamb chops, the locals suggested using our hands.) We truly enjoyed our dinner here. Dinner was about 35 Euros per person without wine.

title_review: Come for tapas rather than the Restaurant
review_preview: To be fair it seems like the best experience here would be in the bar/Tavern area rather than in the restaurant.  They have similar menus and seems like the tapes menu is one diverse and smaller portions of the already really rich hearty dishes. We...
review_full: To be fair it seems like the best experience here would be in the bar/Tavern area rather than in the restaurant. They have similar menus and seems like the tapes menu is one diverse and smaller portions of the already really rich hearty dishes.  We sat in the restaurant area which has a completely different vibe than the bustling downstairs where you walk in. I was a little intimidated by the crowd but which we stayed down there. Up at the top the menu is 3 times the prices of the same things you can get down below.  I got the Callos Tripe dish, I am not familiar with Spanish cuisine but this looked good and was well worth the adventure. Stewed in a thick roux type stew with sausages the Tripe is soft and gets a very smokey and distinct flavour. One of those which unfortunately you can't have too much of, and it becomes overpowering.  Hubby got the suckling lamb chops mostly because the server talked him out of the lamb knuckle, which we kind of wished we had tried. Didn't really appreciate that. The lamb was okay but he wasn't impressed with the fries that came with it.  At the price we paid it's over priced. If you were to do tapas I think is more reasonable.  The place is super tiny and even with a hand full of tables there are 4 servers running around and serving at a good pace. Except when they split my wine bottle. Twice.  There's apparently a bit of history to do with bullfighters hanging out here as of the 1800s.

title_review: The Best Gambas a la plancha
review_preview: If in the area and you love shrimp, you've got to try this place. It can get loud and crowded, and not your white linen fine dining, more of a pub. But the grilled prawns are the best I've had in Spain. Perfectly grilled with...
review_full: If in the area and you love shrimp, you've got to try this place. It can get loud and crowded, and not your white linen fine dining, more of a pub. But the grilled prawns are the best I've had in Spain. Perfectly grilled with sprinkles of sea salt--the chef lets the sweetness and freshness of the huge tender shrimps shine on its own without messing it up with spices. Wow! I devoured the whole plate all by myself and wanted a second had my stomach not been so full. We came here because of all the raves about the gambas a la plancha and it did not disappoint. We also ordered a salad and it was huge. In fact, most plates we saw that came out were huge. We ordered bulls tail stew and that was quite yummy as well. Just wished we had rice to eat with the gravy. When we tried to order another item, the waitress shook her head and told us we already had a lot of food. Glad we heeded her advice. Along with the free sausage tapas, we were stuffed. Our waitress deserves an award for waitress extraordinaire. Fast, efficient and stayed on top of things in spite of a full house with just another waitress working. I have never seen anyone hustle the way she did. Touristy? yes. But what do you expect in Plaza del Sol?  Great food? can only vouch for the gambas plancha, oxtail and tuna salad. And be sure to check out the beautiful facade of this place.

review_preview: You get the sense as you enter that this is a local institution. The walls are adorned with photos of the ( what I presume are ) Spanish glitterati and sporting nobility ) bull fighters, footballers, politicians from days well past. There is an atmosphere...
review_full: You get the sense as you enter that this is a local institution. The walls are adorned with photos of the ( what I presume are ) Spanish glitterati and sporting nobility ) bull fighters, footballers, politicians from days well past. There is an atmosphere of history but the food is not dated in any sense. Fantastic tapas at reasonable prices, great service with very friendly staff. Croquettes were the highlight as was the Milley of Porc. Menu in Spanish and English. Near Plaza Santa Ana. Eat late as its busy or book - tapas in the front - restaurant at the back ( arrived 10.30 and had to wait alittle for tapas ) Even if you just pop in for a beer at the bar and soak up some atmosphere it is well worth the walk from wherever in Madrid you might otherwise be. Our best Madrid meal.

review_preview: On a Saturday night in Madrid, it's pretty hard to find a decent tapas bar! It was quite chaotic at 10pm (hence I would probably recommend making reservations for the good places in advance). We came back to this street as it has some fantastic...
review_full: On a Saturday night in Madrid, it's pretty hard to find a decent tapas bar! It was quite chaotic at 10pm (hence I would probably recommend making reservations for the good places in advance). We came back to this street as it has some fantastic restaurants on it and had dined successfully at another the previous night. We had a glass of wine as we waited for a table and were served by very friendly staff. Not too many staff in Madrid speak English, but our waitresses were pretty good at English. We ordered lamb and a Spanish crab stew with blinis which was divine. The lamb was succulent and perfect. Oh and they had the most amazing home baked bread with was fantastic with a little bit of olive oil. Very nice atmosphere, warm and busy but cosy. Would definitely visit again.

review_preview: My wife and I had planned to eat in the Plaza Santa Ana the night we found Casa Alberto. All of the places in the Plaza seemed identical and we were looking for something more unique. We strolled a block from the plaza and found...
review_full: My wife and I had planned to eat in the Plaza Santa Ana the night we found Casa Alberto. All of the places in the Plaza seemed identical and we were looking for something more unique. We strolled a block from the plaza and found Casa Alberto, a tapas bar that's been around since 1827. We were outside looking at the menu and the server invited us in, we came in and ordered beer at the bar and were offered a delicious snack while we waited for one of the tables in the bar to open up. We didn't have to wait long & we sat down and ordered 3 tapas, all were amazing! We had the veal meatballs, stuffed peppers and a meat ravioli. The guy that runs the show in the bar area is awesome! He suggested that we try the Mascarpone Cheesecake with Rasberry Sorbet for dessert and it was outstanding! We told him how much we enjoyed our meal and he said that we should come back tomorrow night for another dessert. We would have, but sadly this was our final meal in Madrid as we were leaving in the morning. I plan on making Casa Alberto the first place we stop when we return to Madrid! Great value also, if we had eaten in the Plaza we would've spent twice as much, and neither the food nor the atmosphere would have been nearly as good.

review_preview: We stumbled on this by accident and ventured in to try the menu de degustacion de tapas. We were a bit early, so had a drink and tapas and enjoyed the wonderful interior. It may attract quite a  few tourists, so be deemed less than...
review_full: We stumbled on this by accident and ventured in to try the menu de degustacion de tapas. We were a bit early, so had a drink and tapas and enjoyed the wonderful interior. It may attract quite a few tourists, so be deemed less than fully authentic, but for us as tourists it was a great little bar and the waiters were of the traditional sort rather than youngsters. When the kitchen was ready we went into the back room for our meal, again a wonderful atmospheric interior with the walls covered in memorabilia. The service was great, friendly whilst remaining formal, the food was excellent, dishes came out regularly without delays and even though it was a tasting menu, we felt well fed by the end. Altogether there were six small courses, bread, 2 glasses of wine each, water and a gin and tonic each, all for €40 for two of us. This was better value than we had had at other nearby restaurants and much better food. It's not hugely fancy, just nice, well prepared food, and an enjoyable evening. We enjoyed it so much we went back again a couple of nights later, and were still impressed.  It's small and busy so it's good to get there early, or else book.

review_preview: My husband and I (both expats) live in the Las Letras neighborhood, and we walked into Casa Alberto one night for dinner. It looked 'traditional' enough, but we soon realized that the whole place was chock-full with older looking English-speaking tourists, which is generally not...
review_full: My husband and I (both expats) live in the Las Letras neighborhood, and we walked into Casa Alberto one night for dinner. It looked 'traditional' enough, but we soon realized that the whole place was chock-full with older looking English-speaking tourists, which is generally not a good sign in a Spanish restaurant.  We decided to test the quality of the food with our "Rabo del Toro" test. Rabo del Toro or Oxtail stew is a very typical Spanish dish from the south, and we have had some darn good samples in a couple of small taverns in downtown Madrid. We figured, if the Rabo del Toro of Casa Alberto was even better than that of our favorite tavern (which serves it at half the price), then Casa Alberto was a keeper.  Apart from the snooty waiters and chaotic atmosphere (but not in a good way), the food itself was the real disappointment. It had none of the rich smoky flavor of the previous Oxtail Stews we had eaten, and we honestly felt cheated. Plus, I really hate it when restaurants serve you bread without asking and then charge you for it - which is what these guys did.  I think this place may have been very good back in the day, but now it's just a tourist magnet, and completed overrated when it comes to the food. There's lots of better (and cheaper) places to dine out in the neighborhood!

title_review: Locals eat here. Good sign. No fancy prices.
review_preview: We found this down the road from where we were staying after 4 days in Madrid. Planned on going out to a highly rated restaurant a 15 minute cab ride out of town but found it booked out. Bar was crowded but tables available at...
review_full: We found this down the road from where we were staying after 4 days in Madrid. Planned on going out to a highly rated restaurant a 15 minute cab ride out of town but found it booked out. Bar was crowded but tables available at back. Fellow behind bar indicated full but man at top of stairs indicated he would find us a table. Did so by splitting a table for 4. We thought he was laying it on but 20 minutes later not a table available. Heavy carved wood deco and very colorful. Wife reckons it would make a perfect impressionist painting. Food was good and serves generous. My entree of squid and zucchini ravioli with squid ink sauce was terrific. Could have shared between two. The Iberian pork was superb. Cooked medium rare with caramelised onion. Made me aware of how foul our pumped up pork is back home. This tasted like meat unlike pumped up plastic from pen fed animals. So food is ok. Wine good. A red El Moro about €22. This was recommended by a local diner. But it is the vibrancy of place which excels. Full of locals enjoying themselves. We did also. Worth a visit for good meal and environment. Service excellent.

review_full: We were recommend this tapas bar/restaurant by our hotel (Hotel Catalonia Plaza Mayor). We arrived, did not know much about the menu or wine. The waiter, Herman, who looks after the tapas bar, gave us 2 glasses of white wine which went down a treat (wine from Reuda region). The food was excellent - calamari & croquettes. You receive free basket of bread and the bread is so good it reminds me of bread from France. Our wine glasses emptied pretty quick, we looked around to get another, and suddenly it was ordered for us and delivered to us. Food was also efficient in arriving. We ended going back another night & Herman gave us a table ahead of others as we were repeat offenders. He gave us the same wine again, but this time we ordered different food. This tapas bar is buzzing, people jam in standing at the bar and crowding themselves around the tables. I would highly recommend this bar, great atomsphere

For the main course, I ordered beef cheek, my friends lamb cutlet and beef tenderloin (medium) with apple aioli. The first two dishes were okay or even excellent. But the beef seemed to be forgotten in the grill pan. When we took a closer look, it did not look like beef tenderloin at all (more like a pork chop). Well, my friend complained and the waiter took away the so-called beef tenderloin. After ten minutes or so he came back with a double folded entrecote on the plate! My friend gave up. But if they had no beef in the fridge then why pretend? Unfortunately we cannot recommend Casa Alberto to anyone this time.

review_preview: We visited here as a group of six and found Casa Alberto to be one the most friendly and authentic tapas bars and restaurants in Madrid.  We arrived at a super busy time with no prior booking but were still made to feel welcome, we...
review_full: We visited here as a group of six and found Casa Alberto to be one the most friendly and authentic tapas bars and restaurants in Madrid. We arrived at a super busy time with no prior booking but were still made to feel welcome, we received little plates of complimentary tapas whilst waiting for a table and were regularly updated with table progress.  The food was fabulous, a great selection of tasty and authentic tapas and good recommendations from the waiters, in particular the entertaining and knowledgeable Herman.  We found the best atmosphere, feeling the hustle and bustle of a busy tapas establishment was in the bar area as opposed to the restaurant, which appeared a little more sedate, although it was full on both occasions we visited. We would absolutely recommend Casa Alberto to anyone looking for a fun evening with great food.

The barmen (we have seen the main 3 on each of our visits) are delightful, the food, wine and vermut are always good and squeezing into a space at the bar is a joy! title_review: After seven years in Madrid,  this is the place I keep coming back to
review_preview: Alhambra has two restaurants right next to each other but I usually go to the second one to the left seen from metro Sol. I lived in Madrid for a long time and have such great memories from this place. Their grilled pulpo, langostinos, cheeses,...
review_full: Alhambra has two restaurants right next to each other but I usually go to the second one to the left seen from metro Sol. I lived in Madrid for a long time and have such great memories from this place. Their grilled pulpo, langostinos, cheeses, meats...everything on the menu is simply great and the portions are really huge. I recommend you to share the plates to try a bit of everything. Start with a nice salad and some seafood accompanied with a nice Barbadillo wine. Move on to have some meats with a heavy Ramón Bilbao reserva wine. The service here is really great and the price is actually just right and matches the quality without being too pricy. Highly recommended you go and you're in for a fun evening!

title_review: One of my favorite places in the world
review_preview: Each time I get the chance to go to Madrid, or pass by when travelling somewhere else, I always stop at Taberna Alhambra. I absolutely adore this place, the chistorra and the hams are to die for, their selection of wine is exquisite, the tapas...
review_full: Each time I get the chance to go to Madrid, or pass by when travelling somewhere else, I always stop at Taberna Alhambra. I absolutely adore this place, the chistorra and the hams are to die for, their selection of wine is exquisite, the tapas and cañas are one of the best I've tried in the world (comparable to the South of Spain, Cádiz, specifically, which have the best tapas, in my opinion) and the prices are very good and they have very friendly staff. They are usually open until very late at night, which works great when I've had long layovers. I really like this place and I'm very happy I happened to stumble upon it when I first passed by Madrid, because I have always been going back.

We even stopped here again 2 nights later during our last evening in the city!

review_full: If you have time for only one traditional Madrid restaurant - this is your place. Restaurant is on the back - tables are very close to each other and along with traditional decor and frendly staff gives cosyness. Tried Pulpo a la Brasa, Bacalao a la Brasa and Confit de Pato. Confit was FANTASTIC, one of the best I ever tasted. Traditional Madrid garlic-paprika sauce, which they put many dishes gives little bit same taste of everything (octopus and cod dishes we tested). Really great selection of wines.

review_preview: We really enjoyed our meal here and also the atmosphere.  It is definitely high energy.  The manager was friendly and entertaining which made our relatively short wait pass quickly.  There are a lot of meat dishes on the menu.  I had the entrecote de lomo...
review_full: We really enjoyed our meal here and also the atmosphere. It is definitely high energy. The manager was friendly and entertaining which made our relatively short wait pass quickly. There are a lot of meat dishes on the menu. I had the entrecote de lomo which is a steak. It was served medium rare which was perfect for me and tasted very good. My daughter had the oxtail stew. She wanted to try oxtail. It was good but I preferred my steak. It was not a traditional stew you'd find in the U.S. It was four vertebrae with meat from the tail. There was a small amount of juice with it which was the only thing "stew" like. We also shared a grilled mixed vegetable plate. I had sangria and my daughter had a glass of wine. The total bill came to 43 euros. We would certainly eat here again. The place was crowded and people were waiting. This was the only restaurant in Europe I've been to where they brought your check right away. They clearly wanted to free up tables for waiting diners.

title_review: Good Place - Not for Paella though
review_preview: Last month we ate here three times.  The service was good each time and the food the first two was quite good.  We had steak, fries and a couple of other things, not remembered right now, but left with the impression that the restaurant was...
review_full: Last month we ate here three times. The service was good each time and the food the first two was quite good. We had steak, fries and a couple of other things, not remembered right now, but left with the impression that the restaurant was reasonably priced with decent food and good service. Now comes the However. Our last visit, I had researched where to find good paella in Madrid and somehow thought I had come up with this the Alhambra. Since we stayed quite close, I went over to ask if they made paella and they said sure, but only starting at 8:30pm (1st tip off). At around 8:45pm we went over, ordered a bottle of wine and ordered paella for 3. Freshly made paella takes a minimum of 30-45 minutes to cook so we settled in to drink and chat. All three plates of paella were out within 5 minutes. I can't guarante anything, but this paella looked and tasted previously cooked. It was disgusting. Three bites and we were ready to leave. Called the waitress and asked for our check. When she saw us leaving full plates, she asked how we liked the paella, so I told her the truth, that it was terrible. Upside and my kudos for the restuarant management!! She brought us the check immediately. The check did not and I'll repeat this, did not, have charges for the paella. They charged us for the wine and water we had ordered and drank and dropped off the food charges. All in all, this is a good place to eat in Madrid. Would not have gone three times if we didn't think so. Just beware the paella. The other stuff is good, reasonably priced, and the place is alway busy.

title_review: Two times visited - first was excellent, second not so
review_preview: First MealStaying in the hotel linked to this restaurant we first had lunch upon arrival. Picking a tasting menu of 4 dishes our impressions of this place were amazing. The service staff were very helpful in explaining the dishes and were very quick in...
review_full: First Meal Staying in the hotel linked to this restaurant we first had lunch upon arrival. Picking a tasting menu of 4 dishes our impressions of this place were amazing. The service staff were very helpful in explaining the dishes and were very quick in attendance. The venue itself is good visually as it is set within an area that supplies a small courtyard. Our dishes were presented quickly and visually appealing. The taste matched the presentation. Each serving was very generous and showcased great tastes of Spain. We felt that this was a very good introduction to Madrid. Dinner After returning from seeing sights around the city we again chose to eat at the hotel. Unfortunately this experience was the direct opposite to our first. The service staff were rude and unhelpful. We had bought water to take to our rooms and we were told on several occasions that we would have to buy our own. We had purchased drinks at the restaurant and had no intentions of drinking out pre purchased water. After ordering a light meal of 3 tapas our first meal was burnt, our second was not cooked through and the third was forgotten. It was hard to get hold of the staff to inform them of this and at the end we decided to not get it. For this the staff did take some of the price off the bill which was appreciated but the experience was greatly different from our first meal. To sum up, this place is not the cheapest but after our first meal we were satisfied with the experience. As for our second time, it was terrible and not worth the expense (though the burnt plate was taken from the bill).

title_review: Delicious food, but small portion; price on the higher end; good service; interesting dessert.
review_preview: This is a decent restaurant serving quality food with elements from various cuisines (including Asian ones). In this sense, it is not a typical Spanish restaurant.We had mussels croquettes for starter, pork with guacamole & crab in tomato sauce for mains, and their special...
review_full: This is a decent restaurant serving quality food with elements from various cuisines (including Asian ones). In this sense, it is not a typical Spanish restaurant. We had mussels croquettes for starter, pork with guacamole & crab in tomato sauce for mains, and their special white chocolate sweet with lime froth as dessert. PROS:  (1) food was well-seasoned and generally tasty;  (2) service was friendly and rather quick;  (3) the atmosphere was relaxing despite the busy night. CONS:  (1) although the food was good (the crab was particularly memorable), the portions were small, so they won't satisfy hungry diners;  (2) the starter and the mains were delicious, but the dessert (a block of soft white chocolate with lime zest) wasn't our cup of tea; it felt like eating soap... if you like the smell of soap, order it.

review_preview: La Antonita had one on the smaller frontages on a street with a good range of tapas bars but we chose it because the menu looked interesting and we were not disappointed. Each dish we ordered was well presented, a good size for two, and...
review_full: La Antonita had one on the smaller frontages on a street with a good range of tapas bars but we chose it because the menu looked interesting and we were not disappointed. Each dish we ordered was well presented, a good size for two, and very tasty. Ham croquettes were crispy on the outside and meltingly soft inside woth a good flavour. The cerviche combine cherries with fish and prawn, cod tempura was excellent but the showstopper was serrano with guacamole which melted in the mouth and was a good sized portion. Deserts looked inviting but we had eaten sufficient by this stage. Service was helpful and friendly, food arrived at good intervals and menues had good English translations. This was not cheap but was a very enjoyablebmeal and a great find.

review_preview: We were "recruitied" from the street into this resturant when we were very hungry. The atmosphere was nice, with an old church under glass at our feet (no explantion of this anywhere, but we asked), but the place was crowded. We asked for the non-smoking...
review_full: We were "recruitied" from the street into this resturant when we were very hungry. The atmosphere was nice, with an old church under glass at our feet (no explantion of this anywhere, but we asked), but the place was crowded. We asked for the non-smoking section. The menu was printed, but the printer was not working well and the copy we got was so badly printed, we could not read it. The other copy we asked for had obviously been printed by the same printer when it was running out of ink and it was no more legible. The menu I received was half in English and half in Spanish. The problem was that it did not describe the dishes well. There was a chalk board above our heads with menu items and the two were different from one another. I ordered chorizo and I expected a hot, sausage-like dish and instead I received a plate of cold meat on wax paper. While it was delicious, I would have liked some description of what I ordered. There was not much explanation offered by the server either. The grilled vegetables we ordered were delicious! While the food was very good, the portions were not generous and our dinner came to 46 Euros. We left after the meal, intending to order coffee and dessert elsewhere. We did not go back.

review_full: Foodie Heaven with tons of options to eat. The best part is that you can choose the quantity of A PARTICULAR thing that you see on display. The place is definitely more expensive than other say Mercado de San Anton which is small but you will find more local people at San Antonio. The vermouth on tap is super tasty and gets you ready for a gastronomic experience that is the tapa. Being right next to Plaza Mayor, Royal Plaza and Sol area , one can cover that above area and head to Mercado de San Miguel for lunch / dinner. If you have just arrived at Madrid and yet to discover what kind of tapas you will like, it is best to hit this place and experience the variety that is available. This will beat the Tapas tour if you are ko on your own and need some fair idea of what food to try in Madrid. It's definitely more expensive than other places but you get to try super small portions like say 1 peice of something if you wanna try.... I definitely recommend it for  1. Good vermouth on tap 2. Calamaris 3. Cheeses with various options 4. Good Cerveza 5. Decent croquettes 6. GOOD VIBE.

review_preview: I recently reviewed this restaurant in September after discovering it in June 2013 (and after visiting multiple times since then). So, La Antoñita was my favorite place for fancy and delicious tapas. It´s not cheap but I used to think it was worth it –...
review_full: I recently reviewed this restaurant in September after discovering it in June 2013 (and after visiting multiple times since then). So, La Antoñita was my favorite place for fancy and delicious tapas. It´s not cheap but I used to think it was worth it – (amazing food, good ambience, great service). I am originally from London but for the next year, I am living and working in Madrid. Therefore when friends and family come to visit, La Antoñita is where I take my loved ones to impress them and give them a good meal!!!  So, after visiting this restaurant FIVE times in the last FIVE months, I decided to take one of my best friends there on Saturday night for dinner on their terraza/coralla, I booked for 9pm – we got there at around 8.50pm. We were then seated; restaurant was still dead as the Spanish don´t usually go out to eat that early!  We ordered two glasses of wine and bread to start – both good. As we had a late lunch, we decided to just order the patatas bravas, ham croquettes and the ribs as I have had these dishes multiple times here and have loved them each time!  Our patatas bravas came, you could tell they had been rushed as they were literally just fried and thrown into the box. – not crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, just fried. Next came our croquettes – HUGE disappointment, in fact I do not even know HOW these were allowed to be sent out the kitchen! They literally looked like someone had eaten them and then thrown them back up! I´m pretty sure croquettes are meant to be fried and crispy on the outside, these were soggy and broken. Nevertheless, I gave them the benefit of the doubt by eating them and not complaining even though they were cold in the middle, just YUCK!  Now for the huge disappointment, the Mango Ribs! These are usually so tasty! Well cooked, meat falls off the bone, full of flavor type thing. The ones we were served on Saturday looked like they had been boiled, were raw pink on the inside with lots of veins and spots of blood. Tasted disgusting. Bearing in mind these were 15euros for a small slab of mini ribs, at this point I did decide to send these back.  The waitress took them back to the kitchen and asked if we wanted something else, by this point my friend and I were just fed up! We did however (and I don’t know why we did this), order another portion of patatas bravas (I think because we felt like we actually had to order something else). These came, we barely touched them.  What really annoyed me was that I looked around at everyone else´s food and it looked nothing like what we had been served. For the rest of the night, we were stared at by members of staff and given DIRTY LOOKS. My friend and I felt very uncomfortable so we decided to ask for the bill. The waitress actually had the audacity to ask us if we wanted dessert. Erm, no thanks.  Our bill came to 28euros, you´re thinking not bad for dinner?- I wish, we paid that for two small glasses of wine, bread, a bottle of water, TWO mushy croquettes and potatoes. Such a shame.  Even though the food was awful, I was willing to give La Antoñita ANOTHER chance but the rude staff has put me off ever returning here not to mention that it is utterly embarrassing when you take a friend who is only visiting Madrid for the weekend to a terrible restaurant!  I think it is safe to say that La Antoñita have lost a very loyal and valuable customer (pleas bear in mind that when I have visited here in the past, I tend to have cocktails, dinner, dessert and coffee and my bill tips over the 80euro mark for just TWO people).  Do I recommend you go here? NO. – My last words to this restaurant, YOUR LOSS Antoñita.

review_preview: I arrived here quite late by Spanish lunch standards, around 3pm, however upon locating a waitress was seated and they were happy to accept me for lunch (thumbs up!).The service was punctual and friendly, and my minimal Spanish and some mutual effort got us...
review_full: I arrived here quite late by Spanish lunch standards, around 3pm, however upon locating a waitress was seated and they were happy to accept me for lunch (thumbs up!). The service was punctual and friendly, and my minimal Spanish and some mutual effort got us through the ordering process. I was disappointed with the food, unfortanately. The pork carpaccio was thick and hammy, and honestly just didn't taste much of anything. I followed this with a pasta dish which, while the pasta was cooked well was doused in oil to an excessive degree, and just wasn't enjoyable as a result. Having missed breakfast I did finish it, but if I hadn't been starving I would not have. I was surprised at this as this restaurant appears in the Michelin guide and so I expected excellent food. It is perfectly possible I just ordered the wrong things, or that the chef was disinterested due to the lateness of my meal, however going on my experience I would not reccommend this to others, or eat here again while in Madrid.

review_preview: Came in here on a weekday evening for supper after reading the timeout review.  I was pleased with everything from start to finish. My dinner consisted of a goat cheese and walnuts salad with port wine dressing, prawn with couscous and curry (I wanted to...
review_full: Came in here on a weekday evening for supper after reading the timeout review. I was pleased with everything from start to finish. My dinner consisted of a goat cheese and walnuts salad with port wine dressing, prawn with couscous and curry (I wanted to lick the plate), and muscat creme brulee. All done beautifully. The atmosphere was tasteful and friendly. The dinning room was well lighted and never loud despite everybody seemingly having a great time. Service was friendly. Staff was more than willing to make recommendations. The bill of a beautiful three course meal with three glasses of wine came to 48 euro. That's good value for a nice restaurant in Madrid.

title_review: Entered by accident: going back on purpose
review_preview: Wondered by this Galician restaurant in the center of Madrid where dining options are unlimited and most subpar, but this was a refreshing find!  The restaurant is beautifully decorated and attractive. We decided only to stay at the bar and have a drink and try...
review_full: Wondered by this Galician restaurant in the center of Madrid where dining options are unlimited and most subpar, but this was a refreshing find! The restaurant is beautifully decorated and attractive. We decided only to stay at the bar and have a drink and try the food, but we ended up staying and ordering more food because each plate was so good! We ordered the "pescaitios" (which were vegetables, not fish), a "taco"(so good, I wanted 5 more) and some other fried fish (I cant remember the name) and it was all so delicious. They only serve Galician wines. A little more expensive than most places in the area, but the quality of the food is very high.

title_review: Spectacular Portuguese cuisine and warm, friendly service!
review_preview: As a resident of the local Barrio de las Letras neighborhood, after passing by on numerous occasions and noticing the restaurant was always brimming with cheerful customers, I decided to step inside and try the gourmet "Atlantic" cuisine inspired by the latest trends in Portuguese...
review_full: As a resident of the local Barrio de las Letras neighborhood, after passing by on numerous occasions and noticing the restaurant was always brimming with cheerful customers, I decided to step inside and try the gourmet "Atlantic" cuisine inspired by the latest trends in Portuguese cooking. What a discovery! Servers were elegant and exquisitely professional, the ambience was cozy and down-to-Earth, and the food was quite simply delicious. Good portions, reasonable price-quality ratio and the owner, Nuno (an amiable, former member of the Portuguese national ballet), even introduced himself and put the finishing touch on was turned out to be a wonderful Sunday lunch. I'd recommend reserving if possible, especially on the weekends! Good luck to the whole staff of Atlantik Corner!

review_full: We hit this spot after reading a review on Naked Madrid, "I'd cross an ocean for this restaurant". The restaurant is beautiful and service was attentive and fun. Unfortunately, the food was off the day we went.  The Carabinero al carbón was dry with no sauce, so I had to add my wine to the couscous for any kind of moisture. The Bacalao al carbón was also overcooked and dry; and the potatoes were undercooked and raw. My mates Ensaladilla de Pulpo was delicious, while the Costillas glaseadas con melaza y pomelo fresco was a bit raw.  Further, they charge 4 euros for pan & cover, we didn't touch the pan. Truly, I'd skip this place. It's expensive and we left hungry.

title_review: Sad meal for our last night.... 👎🏼
review_preview: Overall for the price this restaurant is just OK.... we had a bottle of wine which was decently priced. For tapas, we ordered the sheep cheese and goat cheese with "hopeful" (aka Carmelized) onion. Goat cheese was amazing (though greasy as it was deep fried)...
review_full: Overall for the price this restaurant is just OK.... we had a bottle of wine which was decently priced. For tapas, we ordered the sheep cheese and goat cheese with "hopeful" (aka Carmelized) onion. Goat cheese was amazing (though greasy as it was deep fried) but had a nice blueberry sauce. We ordered paella for a main based on other reviews which was very salty and sadly lacked in the protein/seafood department. We commented to our sever who didn't care one bit - he was too busy serving a table of 4 men who just ordered their 4th bottle of wine. Restaurant was busy and loud but lacked in the quality department!! . Very sad for our last night in Madrid!!!
