review_preview: Came into this taberna for a drink. The Spanish tiles outside would appeal to most, but is it too touristic? The answer is no. The staff greet and say goodbye to everyone, and it is cozy and all I hear around me at the bar...
review_full: Came into this taberna for a drink. The Spanish tiles outside would appeal to most, but is it too touristic? The answer is no. The staff greet and say goodbye to everyone, and it is cozy and all I hear around me at the bar is Spanish. We ordered a copa de vino tinto del Ribera and a vermut al grifo (on tap), which was in their menu but they did not have. So we got a vermut de la casa (of the house). My husband loves the vermouth (we are kind of vermouth snobs). My wine is great. And we got a free tapa of chorizo and bread sticks. I would make it a point to come back here while in Madrid.

review_full: Having lived in Madrid for 2 years and not having been back for a couple of years it was great to see that the Alhambra is still a great place to meet. Friendly relaxed atmosphere in the heart of the city, tapas is always fresh and tasty, washed down with a few cold ones or a nice glass of wine. When I suggested to my old friends who still work and live in Madrid that we meet there it was a thumbs up from all, still a firm favourite. Would definitely recommend you visit, you will not be disappointed.

title_review: Eat to your heart contend:Mercado de San Miguel
review_preview: If you think that all the Pintxos places you have been in Pamplona, Bilbao, San Sebastián etc. are crowded, wait till you are at Mercado de San Miguel. You literally have to push your way through at anytime of the day. Rubbing backsides with everyone...
review_full: If you think that all the Pintxos places you have been in Pamplona, Bilbao, San Sebastián etc. are crowded, wait till you are at Mercado de San Miguel. You literally have to push your way through at anytime of the day. Rubbing backsides with everyone in the crowd. With the many stalls in the market selling wines, desserts and all sorts of food, you will find that even getting to the display counters is a battle to fight your way through. My advice is to 1st find a seat and settle down before making any attempt to look for food or drinks. Vinod are cheap but given the food is just so so, it is not cheap. Retain your receipts as those are your tickets to go to the washroom for free. It's a good experience but once is enough.

review_preview: Choosing a tapas bar and/or restaurant in Madrid can be a tricky business if your Spanish isn't fluent. We went with the recommendation in our guide book and ended up at Casa Alberto at 7.20pm one evening. Of course, the restaurant in the back wasn't...
review_full: Choosing a tapas bar and/or restaurant in Madrid can be a tricky business if your Spanish isn't fluent. We went with the recommendation in our guide book and ended up at Casa Alberto at 7.20pm one evening. Of course, the restaurant in the back wasn't open until 8pm but that was an excellent excuse to have a beer and try the tapas at the bar. The bar is cosy and somehow manages to balance the needs of the locals and some intrepid tourists. The restaurant food was delicious and the service friendly and efficient. I recommend the Bacalao a la Madrilena - if you can manage a week's recommended salt intake in one mouthful! Delicious.

review_preview: We booked this place in advance as we were impressed with the reviews. The restaurant at the back was busy, mostly with groups of tourists. The service on arrival was a little brusque, but it was efficient. We placed the order and the waiter did...
review_full: We booked this place in advance as we were impressed with the reviews. The restaurant at the back was busy, mostly with groups of tourists. The service on arrival was a little brusque, but it was efficient. We placed the order and the waiter did warn me against my selection of pig's trotter but I chose it anyway. For starters we had croquetas which were good and in a generous portion and smoked salmon, wrapped around cream cheese and prawns which was a bit strange. My pig's trotter main was not enjoyable but it was completely my own fault for ignoring the waiter's advice. My partner's main of lamb chops were boney and gristly, and had a bitter taste. Overall we didn't enjoy the food, but maybe if we had eaten in the tapas bar at the front we would have liked it more. We thought it was overpriced for the quality of the food we had on the night.

title_review: Should have stayed at the bar
review_preview: This place is cool. It was busy. It had atmosphere and style and felt very local and authentic. We waited about 30 minutes for a table and stood at the bar to wait. We were given free beer and a tapas while we waited (good!)...
review_full: This place is cool. It was busy. It had atmosphere and style and felt very local and authentic. We waited about 30 minutes for a table and stood at the bar to wait. We were given free beer and a tapas while we waited (good!) Once our table was ready we were seated at last. My dad got the tripe, and it was a portion big enough for three people. When it comes to tripe I'm not sure that's a good thing. My dad said it was nothing special to boot.  I had the steak and while it was juicy and cooked the way I wanted it was quite stringy and very hard to cut. Really, I needed a steak knife twice as sharp to do the job. The fries were dry and dehydrated.  The service was indifferent... Our waiter just kind of threw our cutlery down in s haphazard way.  Word of warning... They charge for the bread and for a "cover" fee for the linens, silver wear etc.  We should have stayed put at the bar-we would have been much happier!

review_preview: My wife and I stopped in here before a flamenco show. The staff was very friendly and were quick to offer food suggestions. The steak with chimichurri was perfectly cooked and a big portion. The sauce wasn't the typical cilantro/parsley chimichurri that I'm used to...
review_full: My wife and I stopped in here before a flamenco show. The staff was very friendly and were quick to offer food suggestions. The steak with chimichurri was perfectly cooked and a big portion. The sauce wasn't the typical cilantro/parsley chimichurri that I'm used to in the states, but it was very good! Overall, great value for two meals and sangrias. We would come back to Alhambra.

I was glad I was not alone as these portions would have been to much for myself and these were delicious. The staff is friendly and helpful and this restaurant is good for occasions with friends or families without small kids (will be noisy inside). Definitely worth to come back.

title_review: Very tasty and reasonable service, though service abrupt
review_preview: When we walked into the tapas bar, service from behind the bar was slow to acknowledge me and quite curt. We were directed to the tables located opposite the bar and waited there where I was told we would be served by one of the...
review_full: When we walked into the tapas bar, service from behind the bar was slow to acknowledge me and quite curt. We were directed to the tables located opposite the bar and waited there where I was told we would be served by one of the members of staff there. Our drink orders were taken first, and drinks turned out to be quite cheap. The menu was in Spanish only - which wasn't a problem - and the waiters' knowledge of English was not too bad. The bar when we arrived at about 8 o'clock was still quite quiet, but by the end was brimming with people, both by the bar and then people waiting to have our table on the way out. It has a long history in Madrid, and its décor really celebrates what is a traditional tapas bar with few frills, its walls filled with photos, its bar replete with bottles. It was a really visually appealing and warm place to eat in. As for the service, we were disapointed. The waiter that attended to us was very brusque in his manner, as while I was ordering in Spanish, and deciding amongst my family what we were definitely going for from the menu, decided to just walk off and go to another table or to the bar. I thought this was very unusual and extremely rude, and his demeanour for the rest of the meal continued so. The food was no disappointment, and the traditional side of the tapas bar showed itself in well cooked tapas favourites, like patatas bravas and ham croquettes. We also ordered a fresh salad and were given bread and olives, which is standard. Other tapas included a morcilla 'brownie' with goat's cheese on top, which looked and tasted delicious, and I believe we also some Padrón peppers, which are always delicious. Looking on Trip Advisor, there are lots of amazing-looking dishes that we didn't ordered, but would be sure to when/if we visit next time. Our final tapa of the night really took us by surprise - it was called a tortilla invertida. A green pepper stuffed with a potato and egg tortilla, with a sauce on top. It was so surprising to see a traditional tapas bar serve a really accomplished and slightly left-field dish. It was not only a thing of beauty, but made for a really delicious tapa. The bar also had a restaurant at the back with a table service, which seemed to booked up when I enquired. What turned out to be a bit of an offputting service didn't take away from what was a delicious tapas experience, and even better, it was less than a minute's walk from our apartment. The atmosphere by the end was buzzing and very warming, and we were reluctant to leave, were it not for the fact that others wanted our table. We were well and truly convinced we were located in the best part of the city to sample the cream of the crop, in terms of tapas.

The restaurant part which is at the back of the restaurant is a bit pricey particularly if you want a reasonable wine. But worth a visit. Great food. The tapas is OK price wise and excellent quality. The staff were great and helpful and friendly. On our next visit we will go to Casa Alberto again.

review_preview: Our dinner at Casa Alberto can be described at best as very disappointing.  The waiter was unfriendly and rude.  When I began by asking him in Spanish if he speaks English (which other waiters in other restaurants made no fuss about, whether they spoke English...
review_full: Our dinner at Casa Alberto can be described at best as very disappointing. The waiter was unfriendly and rude. When I began by asking him in Spanish if he speaks English (which other waiters in other restaurants made no fuss about, whether they spoke English or not), he looked at me as if I were some form of idiot who either didn’t know that I was in SPAIN or didn’t know that Spaniards speak a different language from English. He then informed me, in Spanish, of course, that he speaks Spanish (in a tone implying “what did you expect?”). The tone was insulting and utterly unnecessary. Despite the menu showing several half bottles of red wine, there were only two available. It’s not a good sign to have a misleadingly long wine list, and not have even the commonly purchased choices in stock. We did end up ordering a bottle and, I'll concede, it was outstanding! We had had delicious tomato salads in two other restaurants at our previous two dinners in Madrid, so we ordered the tomato salad, knowing that ripe, juicy, flavorful, and delicious tomatoes were available. We were served tomatoes that were the kind you get in mid-winter in a US supermarket — tough, unripe, and just plain flavorless. I ordered a veal shank, which was overcooked and floating in tepid bottled gravy, with lukewarm roasted potatoes. My wife ordered a "prey" of pork, which should have been slices of rare and tender roasted pork shoulder. It came out as thin, boneless, extremely tough slices of grilled pork with a very sweet sauce. They were at least rare, but the sauce was really unpleasant. Her potatoes were undercooked french fries. Also, my meal came out of the kitchen first and I had to flag another waiter (ours had disappeared) and a bus boy to finally get my wife’s meal delivered to our table. Casa Alberto seemed to us to sell the kind of food you might get in a museum cafeteria: OK food, but with pretensions. I’d be surprised if anything is prepared to order. I’d expect the kitchen to operate like a cafeteria kitchen. We saw literally only tourists in the restaurant — and it was packed to the rafters with people like us — which was not a surprise. I can’t imagine anyone from Madrid bothering to eat here.

Only thing is it's a little on the pricier side, but we were willing to pay after being disappointed by the quality of food at other places we tried.

review_preview: I had arrived in Madrid late in the day after a grueling 14 hour 3 flight odyssey from Washington state.  After checking into the hotel on Santa Ana Plaza I decided to take a walk and perhaps find a tapas restaurant that was still serving...
review_full: I had arrived in Madrid late in the day after a grueling 14 hour 3 flight odyssey from Washington state. After checking into the hotel on Santa Ana Plaza I decided to take a walk and perhaps find a tapas restaurant that was still serving food this late at night. I stumbled upon this cafe which from the outside looked quite inviting. The waiter greeted me at the door and informed me that while the restaurant had stop serving food tapas at the bar was still available. I ordered a top sirloin in a blueberry sauce and a small beer. While waiting I was served a generous basket of delicious crusty rustica bread along with a plate of green olives in oil with a small fish which I assumed was an anchovy. The steak was maybe 4 oz and amazingly flavorful. It was seared and nearly raw in the middle but was so tender it reminded me of Ahi. I was very satisfied with the light meal and asked for the check which came out to a very reasonable 7.25 Euros. I had not yet changed any money so expected to pay by credit card. This Amex and Visa symbols were prominently displayed in the window outside so I was surprised when the waiter refused the card. Apparently there is a 10 Euro minimum. No problem, I normally would have asked for another beer or glass of wine but fighting jet lag I instead asked him for something "light" to eat in order to make up the difference. The waiter suggested a Russian salad which I wrongly assumed being a salad was light. To my disappointment I was served a large plate of what in America would be a very rich potato salad which was literally drowning in mayo! Although I later learned that this is a summer staple in Madrid I found it to be inedible and pushed it aside after only one or two spoonfuls. The waiter then brought the check with an additional charge of 8 Euros for the salad which even if I liked it was way overpriced. I was not pleased as an otherwise excellent first impression was marred by this incident. The waiter sort of apologized but didn't offer any restitution. I would have gladly settled the check up to 10 Euros and been content and then willing to give the place another chance later in the trip but for now I will pass.

The meal was very good, both of us enjoyed our choices. The service and ambiance was fine, and we were seated very close to the time we had been promised. I'd recommend this restaurant, but unless you want tapas, I'd suggest making a reservation.

review_preview: My wife and I always come to this place when we visit Madrid. It's a proper Madrileno joint bursting with life and atmosphere in the heart of old Madrid. It's divided into bar at the front and slightly more formal dining area at the back....
review_full: My wife and I always come to this place when we visit Madrid. It's a proper Madrileno joint bursting with life and atmosphere in the heart of old Madrid. It's divided into bar at the front and slightly more formal dining area at the back. The walls are covered with photos and memorabilia, particularly bullfighting and Real Madrid. The place itself is quite old and features some interesting features which you can see from the website. The site also features a well documented history of Casa Alberto and the neighbourhood well worth reading. Casa Alberto has a large drinks selection. The food is good quality and reasonably priced. It is not Michelin so as long as you manage your expectations you will be happy. The menu is classic Madrid cooking but also features some dishes with a bit of a twist. We usually eat in the bar area. The staff are always friendly and the place stays open until late. It is emphatically not just for tourists, indeed one of the reasons I love Madrid is the energy of the Madrilenos and this bar seems to very popular with the locals. I would say that this is one of the best bars of its type in the city. Cheers

There coffee drinks looked interesting though, perhaps these or other desserts are worth a try.

title_review: Authentic bar in the heart of Madrid
review_preview: Casa Alberto is in a prime part of Madrid, though sufficiently well hidden down a little back street. The establishment is quite small and split into two; a restaurant at the back and a lively tapas bar with a small number of tables at the...
review_full: Casa Alberto is in a prime part of Madrid, though sufficiently well hidden down a little back street. The establishment is quite small and split into two; a restaurant at the back and a lively tapas bar with a small number of tables at the front. For our visits we stuck to the tapas bar part. For starters, the atmosphere is very lively with tourists and locals in abundance - the best recommendation I have is to bag a spot at the bar or one of the small tables and do some people watching whilst you sip a cana. The food is good solid Spanish traditional fare - there is always a daily specials board which warrants a look - on one of our visits we had a very tasty squid with chick peas and black ink. In short, the food is unpretentious, tasty and interesting. In my opinion this is all enhanced by the service. If you bother to engage with the barmen and try to speak some Spanish (no matter how broken or basic) they will engage with you and make your evening a memorable one. The place can get pretty frenetic at times, but that's part of the fun. The next time I am in Madrid, this will be the first place I will go to to get some food.

title_review: Amazing dishes served at the tapas bar
review_preview: We went for tapas and stood at the tapas counter. We had beer and wine and one tapa, but the dishes we ordered were next level amazing. Their empanada tapas are very good. This place is a bit pricer than some other tapas bar, but...
review_full: We went for tapas and stood at the tapas counter. We had beer and wine and one tapa, but the dishes we ordered were next level amazing. Their empanada tapas are very good. This place is a bit pricer than some other tapas bar, but if you order the right thing, it is more than worth it. We ordered the garlic lamb sweetbreads. They gave a very generous portion for 10.50 euros. It was amazing, so delicious. We also ordered the special, which was beef tongue at 7 euro. I lived in santa monica and currently in hawaii. There is no where in LA where you are going to get this kind of high end elevated food for these prices. This was the best beef tongue i have ever had. It was perfection. We went at a peak tapas dining time. Given that it was so crazy busy, it didnt actually take that long. The bartenders do a great job given the volume they have to deal with. Being American, I'm pretty impatient. The food does take a while, but remember you are in madrid in a tapas bar. The point is to have drinks and talk for a while. If you are hungry, you can order an already made tapas from the counter to have with your drinks like an appetizer until the larger cooked dishes come out. The larger dishes was well worth the wait.

review_preview: Ok, first of all let's be clear on what this review is. There are two zones of this restaurant. First, for tapas, is always busy with people, tapas looked nice and probably it’s tasty. Second zone, for dining, is a little restaurant. We had to...
review_full: Ok, first of all let's be clear on what this review is. There are two zones of this restaurant. First, for tapas, is always busy with people, tapas looked nice and probably it’s tasty. Second zone, for dining, is a little restaurant. We had to book a table one day in advance. They serve typical Spanish food, which is probably not for me. I had pork with caramelized onions, sounds great, I know, but I could not manage to eat second bit after my first one. Pork had a strange strong taste, as it would be pork 100 years old. Actually no one of our company could finish that pork. Oxtail was intense, for men only, I would say. Not my taste, no no no. However, veal meatballs were great, my kids and I myself loved it! Meat was soft, in delicious tomato sauce. Mascarpone & berries dessert was really good one. So you see, mixed impressions! I would not be back but would recommend for Spanish kitchen lovers, as place itself is historical and probably authentic. Although, mostly for tourists now.

title_review: Wonderful food served by very efficient and most friendly waiters
review_preview: Our intention was to find a restaurant especialised on cous-cous, however as we passed by Casa Alberto, we notice how crowded it was, comparing it with other restaurants in that area. Such amount of people could only mean one thing "very good food". Of course...
review_full: Our intention was to find a restaurant especialised on cous-cous, however as we passed by Casa Alberto, we notice how crowded it was, comparing it with other restaurants in that area. Such amount of people could only mean one thing "very good food". Of course there were no tables free in the restaurant area or in the few table opposite the bar counter, so we decided to carry on with our search for the cous-cous place. This we found on the same street but the place was almost empty, only one table with two girls, which after seeing Casa Alberto ambience really turn us off. We decided to go back to Alberto's and have a drink and a tapa or two at the bar, even if it meant standing up. But luck was on our side and a table was freed just as we walked in, We had callous, rabo de toro, croquetas and empanadillas, all very Spanish and very, very tasty. I know the sound of those dishes might put non spaniards off, but I dare them to try it one day, they will not regret it if they like eating. However, for the less daring, this restaurant has a wide selection of dishes that are well presented and seemed delicious. I did not try the, but I saw how other diners enjoyed them. Same I have on my list for my next visit. The young boy that served us was most simpatic and his recommendations were well received, by us and by others. The barman would offer customers different tapas that kept coming out from the kitchen. It was a wonderful discovery and a very satisfying experience that we intend to repeat in our next visit to Madrid. By the way, the relation value for money was very good indeed.

After having dinner (not a cheap one, being honest) and even finishing with a good atmosphere (head waiter left the kitchen to say goodbye to us), our surprise came just today: they finally charged 10 people!!! This is the first time i have such a bad experience in a restaurant and, for sure, 'Casa Alberto' is already removed from the preferred list of restaurants for my company. I wouldn't even think of going there to have lunch/dinner with my family/friends. Quality-price ratio is not worth it and they lost my trust!

review_preview: My wife and I had our first visit to Madrid at beginning of March 2015 and Casa Alberto was not far from our hotel.  What first attracted us was the authentic look, then the fact it was busy and that there were lots of locals...
review_full: My wife and I had our first visit to Madrid at beginning of March 2015 and Casa Alberto was not far from our hotel. What first attracted us was the authentic look, then the fact it was busy and that there were lots of locals filing in and out and once in we were not disappointed. Lovely old decor, experienced and efficient staff and the tapas were great. The bacalao and the deep fried peppers stuffed with oxtail were the highlight, but all of it is fabulous. We popped back in for dirnks and tapas a number of times over the weekend we were in Madrid. Loved it Some reviews make the point that the staff are not very friendly, actually I found them exactly as you'd expect in Spain: efficient, functional, pleasant without being overly friendly, brilliant at their job. Us Brits need to get used to the fact that Spaniards are not big on please and thankyou, it's not rude, it's just how they are, they probably think we are loco for saying please and thankyou (and usually sorry) about half a dozen times each time we buy a drink or food.

review_preview: We went in on a busy Saturday night where there was barely room to move. I asked a waiter if there was any room in the restaurant and was told no but another waiter had a quick look, called us back and we had a...
review_full: We went in on a busy Saturday night where there was barely room to move. I asked a waiter if there was any room in the restaurant and was told no but another waiter had a quick look, called us back and we had a table! The service was absolutely fantastic. We had a beautiful red wine which was a special centenary edition available in a few different restaurants. While we were waiting for our food we were brought 2 complimentary cod croquettes which were divine. For starter we shared ham croquettes which were perfect. I had cod for main which was a little over but still enjoyable and my partner had pork in a sweet onion sauce which he loved. The tarte tatin for dessert was gorgeous. The decor is lovely - really old school Spanish with lots of pictures on the wall. I couldn't fault this place at all. If you want to sit in the restaurant, I'd probably book as we were pretty lucky to get a table.

review_preview: We went there on the Saturday evening and it was hard to secure a place at the bar not to mention a table. But we did it and ordered some of their tapas: tortilla invertida de patatas con pimiento verde, ravioli de calabacín relleno de...

First one was green pepper stuffed with potato omellete - very, very good. Second one - small dish with zucchini, meat and some cheese sauce - rather not impressive, quite average I would say. Mussels very tasty. We had some very good vermouth from the tap. Nice decor with lot of old pictures and photos. The building itself is historic as Cervantes wrote one of his books while living there. Recommended.

review_full: Alberto's was a great find for us. We had checked out the tapas bars along Calle de Jesus that were recommended by Rick Steves and weren't pleased. After checking the web, we tried Alberto's and found great tasting food. We sat in the bar area and ordered Zucchini Ravioli, Mushrooms in Gorgonzola Cheese, and Calamari. They are delicious. With 3 beers, the cost was 35.35 euros. We ate there twice and the quality was consistent. We would also recommend the grilled Octopus and the Bocatin de Calamares (calamari sandwich with aioli). The waiter was attentive and served us extra tapas because he didn't think the food was coming fast enough. There is also a restaurant in the back if you want a full meal. The place was full of locals which we always consider a good sign.

Prices were very reasonable for the amount of food they bring you (which is a lot!). We tried the house salad and were very impressed. The bacalao was also excellent, as were the lomo con pimientas and the albondigas. Everything was cooked to perfection. At the end of the night out waiter brought us complimentary "digestivos", small sweet mixed drinks as a kind of dessert. We loved this restaurant and will definitely be visiting again.

The number of locals was a testimony to its longevity. 2 pm Wednesday lunch and the place was heaving. We only had tapas when we were there, fantastic paprika onion and olives plus a tuna potato salad, both of which were complimentary. We also ordered 2 others, fantastic oxtail stuffed peppers (divine) and black pudding topped with goats cheese (even more divine) 2 beers each, basket of bread 16€!!!!! Truly great spanish institution.

title_review: Traditional Madrid cuisine with an original modern touch
review_preview: Casa Alberto is a 200 year old Madrid Tavern which offers the best food in that classic scenario. You enter and start drinking the house Vermouth or a beer and take a table to try the best dishes of a mixed traditional and modern cuisine....
review_full: Casa Alberto is a 200 year old Madrid Tavern which offers the best food in that classic scenario. You enter and start drinking the house Vermouth or a beer and take a table to try the best dishes of a mixed traditional and modern cuisine. From the fried calamari sandwich finished in an amazing avocado mayonnaise, a reinterpretation of Spanish octopus with potato or a fried calamary with a black ink sauce with chopped vegetables, to very traditional dishes like bull's tail or the callos (tripes dish). All at its best. You can eat at the bar or at the restaurant room and enjoy the service and atmosphear.

title_review: excellent food & atmos, waiters not so much
review_preview: Found this when the restaurant I wanted to go to was full, and unfriendly. Not that this place was particularly friendly either.Problem with solo travel can be wine - ie you're limited to a couple of wines by the glass - here there were...
review_full: Found this when the restaurant I wanted to go to was full, and unfriendly. Not that this place was particularly friendly either. Problem with solo travel can be wine - ie you're limited to a couple of wines by the glass - here there were several half bottles - hurrah! Anyway I enjoyed a standard fino, followed by a good Ribera del Duero.  place was rammed, certainly seems I waited at bar for say 15 mins before getting a table - they are very strict about who's first in the queue, again pleasant for a solo visitor not to be passed by for more profitable customers. I invited a couple waiting at the bar to share my table - turned out well, we didn't food share, but we did taste each others dishes. The black pudding with goats cheese was melt in the mouth (Spanish morcilla is nothing like our UK black pud), followed by delicous pork & beans. 1 fino, 1/2 bottle, a starter, a main €30.  Waiter made sure I got the table at my turn and delivered food, but apart from that discourteous and no finesse. I'd go back for the food and the wine.

Our waiter provided us with an English menu, which is helpful for those of us who have rusty Spanish skills.  We started with a few plates of tapas, the prawns, croquettes and pork with peppers. Prawns were big. Pork with peppers was the best. I literally could eat the croquettes all day long. The waiter also brought us some chicken wings on the house. Bonus. We probably could have just eaten the tapas and stopped there, but we didn't. We ordered the steak with fries. Cooked perfect. Good portion size. When we were done, they brought out a round of shots on the house. Another Bonus. When I go back to Madrid, I will be visiting Taberna Alhambra again.

review_preview: This is not fine dining - on the contrary Taberna Alhambra is a very rustic place, more like a pub than a restaurant. If you like a very lively environment with 50 or so Spaniards (and some tourists) chatting away in a not so large...
review_full: This is not fine dining - on the contrary Taberna Alhambra is a very rustic place, more like a pub than a restaurant. If you like a very lively environment with 50 or so Spaniards (and some tourists) chatting away in a not so large room, creating a loud sound level, this is a place for you! The food in itself is plain but tasty and the waiter in charge (I think his name is Alex) has complete control over what is happening inside the restaurant - and he even manages to keep an eye on what´s happening outside (and waving at people in the street to come in). The price level is quite bearable, not to say very low.  So, if you like this kind of restaurants Taberna Alhambra is the place for you. If you like restaurants where you could dine in peace and quiet, find another place!

review_full: Compared to all the other places in walking distance, this was disappointing. We got attitude, from waiters who regarded us with disdain to food that seemed served begrudgingly. The waiters could not explain what came family style for sharing and what didn't. The " baked potato" was certainly baked, but then it was diced. Nothing came with it, not even basic butter. The grilled veggies were the highlight. The lamb was a literal leg of lamp. Certainly unsightly, though the boys said it was "good," it was just that, no sides. The entire menu is a la carte. Up the stairs to enter, down the stairs for extra seating and no doubt the bathrooms, but I didn't check them out, I do not consider the place accessible. And all that was before the waiter delivered the check, looking over the shoulder of the man paying the check the entire time. Creepy. Yep, that was our experience in a nutshell: creepy.

title_review: Good food, but not much for vegetarians
review_preview: We had been here a few years ago many times and returned on a recent trip. It seemed quite different- much busier and more of a restaurant vibe rather than the tapas bar feel of before. We were glad to see it so busy and...
review_full: We had been here a few years ago many times and returned on a recent trip. It seemed quite different- much busier and more of a restaurant vibe rather than the tapas bar feel of before. We were glad to see it so busy and didn't mind waiting for a table. The food was good but I am now a vegetarian and there were only 3 dishes I could have- tomatoes, roasted peppers or roasted mixed veg. The tomatoes were described as a tomato salad, but in reality was a family sized plate of quartered tomatoes with only some dried oregano sprinkled on them- only €5 though! The roasted peppers and veg were really good. My husband had the gambas al ajillo and thoroughly enjoyed them! Our waiter was great and the atmosphere was busy, noisy and fun- perfect for a saturday night! PS: better description on the menu would be good: the bean stew has pork and the the lentil stew has chicken! This may be traditional, but tourists don't necessariily know these things!

review_full: Recommended this place by a Madrileno and it did not disappoint. The food was delicious, we had sizzling hot gulas en ajillo, bocquerones fritos and the abondigas. The first two were delicious, the abondigas a little more average, but the atmosphere was great, buzzing with people including locals, the prices were reasonable and the service was super attentive and welcoming. When we tried to order a fourth dish, the waiter advised us we'd already ordered enough which was very welcome as a lot of people wouldn't do that. Especially being so central and close to Sol, I would highly recommend this place. They do move you on quickly when you're done but honestly this is for their turnover and it reflects attentive service more than anything.

title_review: Worst dining experience of my life
review_preview: The food was edible but the service (or rather lack thereof) ruined it for me. We stumbled across this establishment at around 1pm today and decided to give it a try after a cursory glance at its online reviews. The initially friendly waiter changed his...
review_full: The food was edible but the service (or rather lack thereof) ruined it for me. We stumbled across this establishment at around 1pm today and decided to give it a try after a cursory glance at its online reviews. The initially friendly waiter changed his tune as the restaurant started getting packed. We ordered the "menu del dia" and the food arrived promptly. I ordered the lobster and rice, however I was not offered a lobster cracker or a lobster fork like other neighbouring patrons. We tried to catch the waiter's attention but to no avail, until we finished our meals... We then realized that we were being ignored completely by the waiter, purposely? I tried to give him the benefit of the doubt but after 20-30 minutes of waiting and trying a few times to request a modicum of service, it was obvious we were being ignored. My suspicions were confirmed when the waiter finally came and yelled rudely "finished?" and tried to rush us out by forcing the bill on us without even offering us coffee or dessert (included in our order). Our ordeal finally ended as we decided it was not worth causing a scene so we left without the coffee or dessert we paid for... I am very disappointed in our first meal in Madrid. I truly hope this is an isolated incident that does not represent the people of Madrid. This has been the worst dining experience of my life (and I've been to countless cities across the world). I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.

Its rare that I feel that I have had genuine value from a restaurant but on this occasion I was blown away.

I will definitely come back when in Madrid.

The total bill for four tapas, two waters and six Sangrias came to 40 euro. It was certainly worth it.

review_preview: Vietnam is causing quite a stir. We arrived at about 9:30 pm having previously reserved. The  restaurant was full by 10:00. From the moment we arrived, the small front-of-house team were kept busy turning away a steady stream of people who wanted to eat here....
review_full: Vietnam is causing quite a stir. We arrived at about 9:30 pm having previously reserved. The restaurant was full by 10:00. From the moment we arrived, the small front-of-house team were kept busy turning away a steady stream of people who wanted to eat here. I guess many of those trying to get a table had read or heard the reviews, raving about the incredible food they are turning out here for a very modest price. I suppose it's worth trying but If you want to avoid disappointment, be sure to book. The food was every bit as enjoyable as reviewers here and in the press have indicated. We had some of the crunchy rice with shredded and ground pork that others have already talked about. It is totally moreish. We also had the nems which were crunchy, succulent and served with the freshest lettuce and herbs to wrap them up in before dipping them into the highly comestible fish sauce based dip. The secreto (a cut of pork that is juicy and succulent) too is sublime. And the crispy, crunchy noodles leave you wanting more. Everything leaves you wanting more, although the food is deceptively filling. We had a bottle of Verdejo and the whole meal was around 60 euros. Outstanding value.  The restaurant is small - maybe 20 covers at most. It's simply decorated in neutral grey but, like Sudestada, the cutlery and linen is good quality and raises the tone of the place. Although we were sat within a meter of our neighbours, we didn't feel overheard here. You couldn't describe it as intimate, but it's a couple can easily enjoy a nice dinner together here. Service is helpful and attentive but not over-bearing. The staff may attempt to speak English (to a reasonable standard) even when it's not necessary. Normally, I find this slightly irritating but the staff are charming and it would be harsh to be irritated by their friendliness. Honestly, it would be harsh to find much to fault with anything here. They are serving excellent food - good quality ingredients and well-executed, imaginative dishes - at extremely reasonable prices. If you enjoy Asian food, you'll struggle to find better in Madrid. As a result, you'll struggle to get a table here. It's hotter than a hot pot on a hot plate in a heatwave. Book ahead.

review_full: The food was absolutely great! Not a very extense menu, I would miss a wider choise in order to come back more often. Dishes are very complete, and can be ordered spicy if you like (this is usually an issue in Spain, as spaniards do not tolerate spicy food). The place is simple, the environment could be a little more looked after (better decoration and a more cosy lighting, but this is also a very common issue in Spain). But the food is so good that it makes up for all the improvable details. I totally recommend this place if you would like a real and tasty Vietnamese dinner.

Good prices, for 2 persons, 2 entrees and 2 mains, the bill was 42euros. I'll defintely be back before leaving Madrid.

review_preview: This restaurant was not far from our accommodation and being lovers of Vietnamese food we had to try it. The service was quick, and food fresh and flavourful! The food and drinks were reasonably priced too. I would definitely recommend. It is worth keeping in...
review_full: This restaurant was not far from our accommodation and being lovers of Vietnamese food we had to try it. The service was quick, and food fresh and flavourful! The food and drinks were reasonably priced too. I would definitely recommend. It is worth keeping in mind that it does not open until 8pm as we walked by one night and thought it was closed.

title_review: Very good to discover the vietamese cuisine
review_preview: We went there on a Saturday night, to have dinner 5 of us.  Luckily we had booked the table otherwise, we wouldn't have had a table, the place is very small.  Menu wise, only 5-6 starters, same of the main dishes and desserts not made...
review_full: We went there on a Saturday night, to have dinner 5 of us. Luckily we had booked the table otherwise, we wouldn't have had a table, the place is very small. Menu wise, only 5-6 starters, same of the main dishes and desserts not made on the premise. We shared the spring rolls and the nems, both were very good, best one were the nems. After, a lot of us had the soup, which to my taste was not tasty enough. The broth was a bit tasteless. I had better outside Spain but I have been told this restaurant was the best of Madrid... So for my friends who were discovering this type of food, it was a good surprise. One took the squid plate and it was very tasty. Dessert... you don't go to a Vietnamese restaurant to eat dessert...  Service is very friendly and efficient.

review_preview: The restaurant opened late, like most restaurants in central Madrid.  Inside was pleasant, with one Spanish, one vietnamese, servers.  The menu was short, cooked to order.  The mixed plate of starters was very pleasant, but mild to the point of bland.  The main courses were...
review_full: The restaurant opened late, like most restaurants in central Madrid. Inside was pleasant, with one Spanish, one vietnamese, servers. The menu was short, cooked to order. The mixed plate of starters was very pleasant, but mild to the point of bland. The main courses were even more bland, so disappointing. The best dish was the pho, as one might expect. Oddly, were were given menus, made our choice of dishes, and were told that we had chosen badly - perhaps, but it was our choice, we were the customers; they then brought the wrong dish, when we refused it, they said they were "correcting" our choice (I've never had that in a restaurant before)
